title: How to Do Scholar's Mate in Chess

steps.headline: e4  - Move your king's pawn forward two squares (E2-E4).
Bc4  - Move the king's bishop 3 squares out through the gap, so that it threatens your opponent's king-side bishop's pawn, the one on square F7 (F1-C4).
Qh5 - Move the queen diagonally out 4 squares, so that it's also attacking the F7 pawn (D1-H5).
steps.description: At this point, someone who has seen Scholar's Mate before will know it's coming. See the section below for how black can block the ploy at this point. EXPERT TIP																															Vitaly Neimer																International Chess Master								Vitaly Neimer is an International Chess Master and Certified Professional Chess Coach with over 15 years of training experience. He has been a part of the United States' Webster SPICE national chess champion team and is also a two-time Israeli national chess champion. Vitaly Neimer			International Chess Master				Scholar's Mate exposes your queen. If you go for Scholar’s Mate against someone who knows how to defend against it, you will get into a worse position. This is because when you play Scholar’s Mate, you have to develop your queen straightaway, which leaves her open for attack.

steps.headline: Qxf7 - Take the king's bishop's pawn (F7) with your queen.
steps.description: You can take the F7 pawn using your bishop instead of the queen, but this won't result in checkmate.

steps.headline: Play your first move however you want.
... d5/e6 - Move your queen's pawn forward two spaces or your king's pawn forward one space, so that white's bishop is no longer attacking F7.
... Nh6/Qe7/Be6 - Do anything that protects the square on F7.
steps.description: Some examples given are moving the knight G8-H6, or the queen D8-E7 or the queen's bishop C8-E6.

steps.headline: Alternatively, and this is recommended, block the Queen's attack on F7.
steps.description: If the Queen is on F3, use F7-F6 or G8-F6. If the Queen is on H5, however, do not use G7-G6, unless you have a piece on E7 or E6 (in front of the King). Otherwise, white moves their Queen to E5, forking the Black King and Rook - the check must be dealt with, and the white Queen wins the black Rook.

text: Performing the Move Play white.  e4  - Move your king's pawn forward two squares (E2-E4).  Bc4  - Move the king's bishop 3 squares out through the gap, so that it threatens your opponent's king-side bishop's pawn, the one on square F7 (F1-C4).  Qh5 - Move the queen diagonally out 4 squares, so that it's also attacking the F7 pawn (D1-H5). At this point, someone who has seen Scholar's Mate before will know it's coming. You can take the F7 pawn using your bishop instead of the queen, but this won't result in checkmate. Checkmate!  Preventing Scholar's Mate as Black Play your first move however you want.  ... d5/e6 - Move your queen's pawn forward two spaces or your king's pawn forward one space, so that white's bishop is no longer attacking F7.  ... Nh6/Qe7/Be6 - Do anything that protects the square on F7. Some examples given are moving the knight G8-H6, or the queen D8-E7 or the queen's bishop C8-E6. Alternatively, and this is recommended, block the Queen's attack on F7. If the Queen is on F3, use F7-F6 or G8-F6. If the Queen is on H5, however, do not use G7-G6, unless you have a piece on E7 or E6 (in front of the King). Otherwise, white moves their Queen to E5, forking the Black King and Rook - the check must be dealt with, and the white Queen wins the black Rook.
